repnme.cdata!:
Benin - Public Enterprise Sector
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the project is
            satisfactory. There are four major lessons emerged from the
            project: a) Strong government commitment and participation
            in the design and implementation of a Public Enterprise (PE)
            Reform Program is a sine qua non condition to the success of
            reforms. b) In 1985-86, when the project was being prepared,
            the approach to PE reform centered around restructuring and
            strengthening PE management and financial performance, while
            maintaining them in the State portfolio. In retrospect, the
            Bank should have included privatization and private sector
            participation in the project objectives instead of focusing
            solely on rehabilitating viable PEs and liquidating
            non-viable ones. c) An efficient project implementing agency
            played a key role in the design and implementation of the
            Divestiture Program. d) The inability of project funds to
            cover the severance pay resulting from the liquidation of
            PEs was one of the major causes of delays in closing
            liquidations. e) Consensus building and public information
            campaigns to seek support of stakeholders and civil society
            should have been an integral part of the project.

repnme.cdata!:
Benin - Public Enterprise Sector
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This project aims at assisting Benin in
            rehabilitating its public enterprise sector. At the sector
            level, the project will support the Government in
            implementing an agreed program of reforms aimed at (a)
            improving the management and operation of the public
            enterprise sector and (b) curtailing State involvement in
            the economy. This program will encourage private sector
            participation and more careful screening of new public
            undertakings to ensure their economic and financial
            viability. At the enterprise level, (a) diagnostic studies
            will be conducted for selected state-owned enterprises to
            assess their potential viability, and liquidation plans will
            be prepared for those enterprises found uneconomic.
            Additionally, (b) rehabilitation will be undertaken in two
            stages for those enterprises diagnosed as viable. In the
            first stage of rehabilitation, an emergency program will be
            implemented to arrest their further deterioration. In the
            second stage, a full rehabilitation program setting specific
            conditions for efficient and profitable operation, will be
            carried out. To accomplish this, the project will comprise
            technical assistance, a credit component for enterprise
            rehabilitation, and financing of training and redeployment
            of staff laid off.
